title: 110_hr1944
content: The Act titled "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" amends Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new subchapter for screening, rehabilitation, and treatment for traumatic brain injury. The Secretary is required to establish a screening program for veterans eligible for hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care to screen for symptoms of traumatic brain injury. A report must be submitted annually to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs with information on the number of veterans screened, prevalence of symptoms, and recommendations for improving care. Sec. 1792 of the legislation mandates a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation for veterans, including residential, community, and home-based care. The program will be implemented in four designated polytrauma network sites, with eligibility criteria for veterans to receive care. Recommendations for improving care and services for veterans with traumatic brain injury symptoms are also included. The program developed under subsection (a) provides care for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injury who are unable to manage daily activities without assistance. Eligibility criteria include serving in combat operations after the Persian Gulf War and being diagnosed with traumatic brain injury. The program provides care for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injury who cannot manage daily activities without assistance. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress on the program's operation, number of veterans served, and annual cost. Additionally, traumatic brain injury transition offices are to be established at each Department polytrauma network. The Secretary is required to establish traumatic brain injury transition offices at each Department polytrauma network site to coordinate healthcare and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. The offices can arrange for healthcare and services through cooperative agreements with public or private entities. Additionally, a traumatic brain injury registry is to be established and maintained by the Secretary. The Secretary is mandated to establish traumatic brain injury transition offices at each Department polytrauma network site to coordinate healthcare and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. The offices can arrange for healthcare and services through cooperative agreements with public or private entities. Additionally, a traumatic brain injury registry, known as the 'Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry,' is to be established and maintained by the Secretary. The Secretary is required to establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry to collect medical data and relevant information on individuals seeking care or compensation for disabilities associated with service. The Registry will notify listed individuals of significant research developments on health. The Secretary will notify individuals in the Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry of important research updates on the health effects of military service in specific theaters of operations. Subchapter IX of title 38, United States Code, includes provisions for screening, rehabilitation programs, transition offices, and a registry for traumatic brain injuries. The Secretary must implement these requirements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act.
